snippet: For many hourly workers, paper paychecks have been replaced by prepaid cards, which often involve fees that can quickly add up and take a bite out of their pay.
abstract: Growing number of American hourly workers now receive their paychecks in form of prepaid debit cards, leading to mounting frustration as withdrawal fees eat away at their income; charges are so persistent that some workers make less than minimum wage after they are taken into account; companies say cards mean significant savings in payroll system.

byline.original: By JESSICA SILVER-GREENBERG and STEPHANIE CLIFFORD

lead_paragraph: For many hourly workers, paper paychecks have been replaced by prepaid cards, which often involve fees that can quickly add up and take a bite out of their pay.

headline.main: Paid via Card, Workers Feel Sting of Fees
headline.print_headline: Paid via Card, Workers Feel Sting of Fees
